abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Lagos Metropolitan
            Development and Governance Project (LMDGP) for Nigeria were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            Bank teams should be cognizant of the prevailing political
            economy and calibrate the complexity of projects
            accordingly. A stand-alone case study is carried out to
            extract lessons learned from LMDGP in a more systematic
            manner, provide in-depth analysis of the modalities of urban
            sector engagements in a mega-city like Lagos, and make
            recommendations towards the structure and manner of
            engagement in such settings. Projects well vested into
            existing institutions are less vulnerable to the presence of
            political capital and may be better suited for complex
            environments like that of Lagos. Simultaneous deployment of
            various lending instruments proved to be effective in
            achieving desired outcomes. Lack of transfer of knowledge,
            right skill mix, and appropriate background in task team
            leaders (TTLs) and sector specialists affects the
            relationship with the client and poses a risk to
            implementation. When the Bank's and the client's
            commitment to safeguards policies and their practical
            implementation diverges significantly, both the Bank and the
            client should be upfront and eliminate instances where
            investments will trigger such policies.
